newsitem.title: DENMARK: Court reserves judgment in Danish EU dispute.
newsitem.headline: Court reserves judgment in Danish EU dispute.

text.p: A court setting the boundaries for a legal challenge to Denmark's European Union membership adjourned on Friday without giving a ruling.

It said it would deliver a judgment next week, on a day to be announced later. The case was brought by 11 Danes who say assignment of national authority to EU institutions contravenes the country's constitution.
At Friday's hearing lawyers for the challengers asked for transcripts of cabinet and parliamentary debates and decisions dating back throughout Denmark's EU membership to be entered as evidence.

The government, which wants debate confined to events subsequent to the 1992 Maastricht acccord, said that assembling and examining such a mountain of documents would delay proceedings until the year 2010 and was in any case unjustified.
"The appellants are simply trying to go on a fishing expedition," government lawyer Karsten Hagel-Soerensen told the court.

Ultimately at stake in the case, expected to last at least two years, is whether Denmark can carry on as a member of the EU under existing terms, or must choose between renegotiating membership and attempting to amend the constitution.
Lawyers say that whoever wins the opening procedural stage will have an advantage when the substantive case comes to court next year.
